text: Lucy takes a deep breath, then pulls away from the house. Dog next to her in the passenger seat. She drives down the road, gaining speed. She suddenly stops, remembering something.

Shit. Sorry. She puts the car in reverse. Backs up until she is next to the mailbox. She reaches out the window, opens the box and puts an envelope inside. She strains to reach the flag. The dog watches. She finally succeeds in pulling the flag to the upright position.
Okay. She puts the car in gear. It disappears down the road. ON the raised red flag.

As Lucy drives south, the Lake on her left. She passes a sign: CHICAGO 60 MILES. Traffic gets denser as she approaches the city. Soon the skyline is right on top of her and she's in it, at the height of the morning rush -- crowds, traffic, noise, energy.

She pulls up outside an APARTMENT BUILDING on a densely- packed North Side street. It's a very new building, cold and sterile. The contrast with the tranquillity of the Lake House is striking. She parks the car, gets out. Takes a moment to absorb the change in her surroundings. Then she starts to unload her things. END CREDITS.

A very ordinary one -- metal, mounted on a post, hinged red flag on the side. The flag is down. The SOUND of waves lapping the shore. PULL BACK. Beyond the mailbox is LAKE MICHIGAN, endless and blue-gray on this overcast winter morning. And on the Lake, hugging the shore, is a LAKE HOUSE. This house, unlike its mailbox, is striking. It’s at the end of a narrow jetty or walkway that shoots out into the Lake. It is perched on stilts right above the water, where it seems to float. Its design is modern, and in another setting it might be slightly austere, but here the fit with its surroundings is so perfect that the overall effect is one of serenity. It is dawn. A smudge of sun can be seen rising in the space between the sun and the surface of the Lake.

LUCY FORSTER, 30, lovely, watches the sunrise through a huge window that faces the water. After a while and with evident difficulty, she tears herself away. She pulls on a coat and goes to the front door. The house is empty; Lucy is moving out. She opens the door and takes a final look back. Her eyes fall on someone.
You coming or not? A SMALL DOG is hesitating in the middle of the room.
Last chance...
Lucy walks across the jetty to the road, where her car is waiting, packed full of bones. The dog trots after her.
The corridors of a huge urban hospital, crowded with PATIENTS, FAMILIES, ORDERLIES. It’s chaotic and loud. Lucy comes in. She walks to the main desk, tries to flag down a busy ATTENDANT.
Excuse me?
Just a minute, okay? Lucy waits for a minute, then tries to catch the Attendant again as she blows past.
Excuse me, I need to -- The Attendant hands her a clipboard.
Just fill this out and wait over there for me, okay? Lucy hands it back.
No, I’m Doctor Forster. I’ma new resident. They told me to report here.
Oh, I’m sorry, Doctor. You need to find Dr. Klyczynski. She should be around here. Older lady, kinda tough, like this tall...
ANNA KLYCZYNSKI, 45, no-nonsense manner, walks fast down the corridor. Lucy next to her, trying to keep up. Klyczynski hands her a big stack of files.
You’re covering 22 patients on rounds today, this floor and the next.
Twenty-two? (CONTINUED)

Quiet morning. If you get into trouble you can beep me, but try to keep it to a minimum. The med students are supposed to help you out with scut work. If you can find one. Lucy is looking a little dazed. They pass a patient on a bed in the corridor. Klyczynski flags down a NURSE.
What’s he doing here? I ordered an immediate MRI.
Transport said about four hours.
Shit. All right. She turns to Lucy, takes the files back, points.
Doctor Forster, push him down to MRI -- that’s a left, another left, a right, elevator to two, follow the signs. Then hustle back here for rounds...
Lucy with a stack of charts, reeling around, trying to find her next patient. She’s lost in the busy corridors. Another young woman doctor, MADHVI PATEL, appears, glances at her chart.
Wrong floor. Lucy makes a frustrated sound. Patel guides her to an elevator.
Takes a while to get your bearings. I’m Madhvi. You’re the new resident, right?
(nods) Lucy. Forster. (CONTINUED)
Where did you do your internship?
A little community hospital. Up on the North Shore.
Well, just think of this as a little community hospital, only with more gunshot wounds. She smiles, but Lucy doesn’t acknowledge the attempt.
Lucy comes off shift, very tired. Patel and another resident, TOM COSTELLO, are changing clothes to go home. They nod at Lucy. She smiles wearily.
How was your first night?
I’m... not sure.
Nor should you be. A state of dazed near-panic is normal for the first few months. Lucy smiles politely.
Luckily there is a cure.
The Cove.
The Cove.
What’s that?
Bar around the corner. Open all night. Acceptable burgers. Cheap beer in unwashed glasses.
It’s heavenly. (CONTINUED)
Lucy realizes they’re inviting her to come with them. She hesitates.
Thanks. Better not. I’m dead.
We all are.
And I’ve still got a lot of unpacking to do... Patel and Costello nod. If they’re put out by her refusal, they don’t show it.

Next time, then. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT Lucy comes home. Her apartment is small, sterile. She hasn’t had time to unpack and boxes are strewn everywhere. As she enters, her DOG LEAPS UP on her, WHIMPERING. Lucy jumps, startled, then puts the dog down, goes into the kitchen and flicks the light on. Nothing happens.
(mutters) Need light bulbs. She opens the (bare) fridge for the light. She pours dog food into a bowl, emptying the bag.
Need dog food. And human food...
Her bedroom is as functional and depressing as the rest of the place. A loud SQUEAK as she walks into the room.
Fix loose floorboard. Lucy goes to the window. Outside -- a solid wall of other buildings, other windows. Very hard even to see the sky. She sighs. (CONTINUED)
Need view. She closes the blinds.

ON the mailbox, its flag still up. FIND a PICKUP TRUCK parked at the edge of the jetty. Its back is piled with furniture and moving boxes. A MAN is moving in to the house. Working alone, he heaves a large armchair off the truck and wrestles it along the jetty.

The man plugs in a lamp and switches it on. JULIAN, 30, tall, moody good looks. He surveys the place, pleased. He doesn’t have much. A stereo, some books, the armchair. But the spare furnishings fit with the austere beauty of the house. He looks out the window at the Lake.
Julian stocks up on groceries at a local shop. The young STOREOWNER and his WIFE behind the counter.
New in the area?
(smiles) More or less.
You’11 like it. Especially since it warms up a little. (indicating groceries) Let us get you some boxes for all that.
Okay, thanks. (CONTINUED)
His wife goes to take an empty box down from a high shelf. She is visibly pregnant. The Storeowner hurries over.
No, honey, let me.
Julian pulls up with his groceries in the back of the truck. He notices the mailbox with its raised flag. He stops and opens it.
Julian sits in his chair by the window, silhouetted against the moonlit Lake outside. A beer in his hand. He opens Lucy’s letter and reads.

‘Dear New Tenant. Hi and welcome to your new home and congratulations, etcetera. It’s a wonderful place, as you already know, and I’m sure you’ll love living here as much as I did. I’m the previous tenant by the way. Julian looks puzzled.
‘The post office is forwarding my mail but I wondered if you could send anything that might slip through. My new address is below. Thanks.’ (beat) “P.S.’ Julian flips the letter over.

(reads) ‘Sorry about the paw prints by the front door. They were there when I moved in. Same with the box in the attic. I think it belongs to the owner.’ Julian stares at the letter.  10. He goes to the front door. The floor is clean. Nothing outside either.
Julian opens the door to an attic crawl space. He looks around. It’s empty. No boxes.
Julian shrugs, crumples the letter and throws it away.
Lucy walks up the stairs to the El, alone against the tide of people walking down -- they are coming home from work as she heads in for a night shift.
An ICU PATIENT in crisis. MONITORS BEEPING and flashing red. Lucy runs in, swiftly begins CPR, asks a nurse to prepare a syringe. Klyczynski appears and stands at the door, watching Lucy closely.
You all right? Lucy keeps working. The patient’s crisis passes. The monitors quiet.
I think we’re okay. Klyczynski nods.
Lucy checks on a PATIENT -- teenage girl lying awake in a darkened room, watching TV.
Hey. You’re supposed to be asleep. (CONTINUED)
I know, but --

Sorry. Sometimes I’ve got to play bad cop. Lucy goes to switch off the TV. She pauses. It’s showing Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman -- the long, long lingering kiss from Notorious. Lucy stares at it, transfixed. Then she sits down on the edge of the bed to watch. The girl looks at her, surprised. Klyczynski nods.

My favourite part. INT. LUCY’S BEDROOM - DAWN After work. Lucy prepares for bed, a blindfold around her neck. She goes to the window to close the blinds against the morning light. She notices something outside. She gets up on tiptoe, straining. Then she pulls a chair over and stands on it.
By standing up high at the extreme edge of the window she can just make out, through a gap in the buildings, a tiny sliver of Lake Michigan. The sun is just coming up.
She stands on the chair, staring at it.
THROUGH the Lake House window we can see the sun rising, huge, over the Lake. Julian is up, lacing up work boots.

Julian pulls up in his truck, arriving at a Lakeside building site -- dozens of future condos, now mostly foundations and a few half-finished frame skeletons. It’s a big operation.  12. An office set up in a large trailer on the site. Julian prepares for the day, consulting plans and schedules. MONA JAFFE (30s, brisk, stylish) on the phone.

That’s right, each luxury residence has a private Lake view... They’re not available for viewing quite yet, but if you’d like me to add you to the list... yes, we absolutely expect to be ready on schedule. She throws a “right?” glance at Julian. He nods reassurance.
Dozens of Men working at various places around the site. FIND Julian walking quickly, conferring with MULHERN (40s, construction foreman, hard look).
I’d like to get the foundation for number 17 dug today. Mulhern looks at him with barely-disguised contempt.
I know you’re kinda new here.
What?
I can’t get to that at least ‘til next week.

(smoothly) Come on, Mulhern, that’s bullshit and you know it. Take Clemens and Rodriguez off roofing, Jorge can run the backhoe they’re not using on fourteen, and grab four or five of the other guys sitting on their asses on seven and ten -- Paulie, Frank, Carlos, Danny, and what’s his name, the tall kid, Rafael. Mulhern blinks.
Right.  13. Julian is the last man at work on the site at the end of the day. He hauls away some garbage and scrap. He’s about to throw out a couple of half-full cans of paint. He stops.

Julian kneels on the jetty, applying a fresh coat of paint to the weather-beaten boards. He finishes, pleased with the result. He begins putting his supplies away. Behind him, a small dog, a stray, trots up the road. Julian doesn’t notice. The dog looks at the jetty for a second, then walks right into it, into the fresh paint. Julian sees.

Hey! He tries to grab the dog but it runs down the jetty. Julian has left the door to the house open and the dog runs inside. Julian is about to follow when he stops suddenly. ON THE FLOOR going into the house is a trail of PAW PRINTS.
Julian digging determinedly through his garbage. Near the bottom, he finally finds what he’s looking for: Lucy’s note. He stares at it.

Lucy heading out for lunch, her coat on. (We note the nurse’s station is decorated with paper hearts, etc.) As she exits the hospital, she realizes it is SURPRISINGLY WARM. She smiles, opens her coat.
Lucy eats her lunch in the large park, the Lake on one side, the city skyline on the other. (CONTINUED)

The park is crowded on this gorgeous day. Heavy traffic on Lake Shore Drive beyond. Lucy squints into the sunlight gleaming off the Lake. Sounds nearby -- a BELL TOLLING noon. Children laughing, yelling. A pair of OLD MEN on the next bench over.
What’s with the damn weather? 60 degrees on Valentine’s Day?

It’s global warming. Buckingham Fountain is not far off. It sends up a huge plume of water. Lucy gets up and starts towards it. She runs a hand through her hair, enjoying the feel of the sun on her face, some of the tension leaving her. Suddenly, a horrible SOUND -- a high-pitched grinding SQUEAL. Lucy looks around. A HUNDRED YARDS AWAY -- on the opposite side of the fountain from Lucy -- a double-length city bus is trying to stop. It’s going quite fast even though from the sound of things, the driver is absolutely crushing the brake. Lucy just registers all of this -- the sound, the bus -- before she notices the MAN standing directly in the bus’s path. There is nothing to be done; it is inevitable and almost immediate -- the man being struck by the bus, and his small, distant figure arching into the air ten or fifteen feet before crashing onto the pavement. The faint sound of the impact reaches Lucy a half-second later, because of the distance. Lucy automatically pulls out her cell phone and dials. She speaks calmly.

We need an ambulance in Grant Park, near Buckingham Fountain. A bus has struck a pedestrian: Get an EMS crew here now. She begins running.  15. Traffic is snarled around the halted bus. PEOPLE gathering. Lucy runs up, starts pushing through the crowd.

I’m a doctor. Let me through. She reaches the man, who is lying twisted, his face bloody, obscured. She can’t move him because of risk of neck injury; there’s not very much she can do except for feel for a pulse, listen for breath. An ambulance pulls up. Two EMTs jump out.
Get a back board! One does. They strap him into it, Lucy working to get a pulse. The other EMT kneels to assist Lucy. They work intensely for a moment. Then he shakes his head.
He’s done. Lucy keeps working as if she hasn’t heard. The EMT puts a hand on her shoulder.
Doctor. Beat. Lucy finally stops. She gets up. The EMTs pull a gurney out of the ambulance and prepare to remove the body.
Lucy pours herself a cup of coffee. Her hands are shaking. She takes a deep breath, willing them to stop. They do. Anna Klyczynski has been watching her.
I heard about Buckingham Fountain. EMTs said you fought hard for the guy.
Yeah, I really knocked myself out. (CONTINUED)
Beat.

I had a case once. Routine heart surgery. They invented the word ‘routine’ for this kind of surgery. He died on the table. His body just chose that time to go. It was nobody’s fault, and there was nothing I could have done differently (beat) I couldn’t sleep for weeks.
Thanks. I’m fine. She turns to go.
Lucy? Lucy stops.
You have anyone in the city? Any friends? Family? Lucy shakes her head.
Do me a favor. On your day off, get as far away from here as you can. Okay? Go someplace where you feel... most like yourself.
Julian, on his way to work, slips a note into the mailbox and raises the flag.
Lucy driving north out of the city. The day is clear and bright, sun gleaming on the water.  17.

Lucy buys lunch in the same grocery we saw before. Same couple running the store. The Wife is behind the counter. She bends up. She recognizes Lucy. STOREOWNER’S WIFE Hey. We haven’t seen you for a while. How’s Chicago?
Okay. STOREOWNER’S WIFE What are you doing back here?
Just needed to get out of the city. When the weather’s like this, you’ve got to. STOREOWNER’S WIFE I know it -- What is it, sweetie? to pick up a TODDLER, about 2, who has just run
Hi there. STOREOWNER’S WIFE Say hi.
Hi.
Julian, working, eating a sandwich. The day hasn’t gotten much warmer and the wind is blowing strongly. Mona stops by, heading to the office with her lunch.
Trailer’s nice and warm.
Love to. Can’t.
(looks at the sky) God, it’s really miserable. Don’t catch a cold or anything on me, all right?  18.
(grins) I never get sick. She follows him as he works.
You find a place to stay yet?
Yeah. Just outside of town, up the shore a little bit.
Up the shore...? I don’t... Wait, not that house with the thing, the walkway thing, and the stilts...
Right.
That’s not on the Lake, it’s in the Lake. That place has been standing empty for years. What made you take that?
Well, I --
Oh, goddamn it. Her high heels are sinking into the muddy ground. She puts a hand on Julian’s shoulder as she pulls her feet free. One shoe stays stuck. Julian gets it out for her.
Thanks.
Get yourself some boots. Mona nods, smiles at him, watches as he wipes off her shoe for her.
Lucy throws a stick, playing fetch with her dog on the beach, wind whipping her hair. Sun low on the horizon. Soon it will be time to go back, but she’s in no hurry to.  19.
They come over a dune and the DOG BARKS.
The LAKE HOUSE, not far off. The dog runs towards it.

She follows, keeping up. They approach the house. The dog trots over to the jetty but Lucy picks him up before he can run across. She looks at the house for a moment. It is empty, silent. Lucy turns to walk away. Then she notices the mailbox with its raised flag. Acting on an impulse, she opens it. INSIDE is a single envelope. She pulls it out. To her surprise, it is addressed to her.
Lucy sits parked outside the House, reading the letter.
(reads aloud) ‘I got your note. Is it supposed to be some kind of joke? If it is, I don’t get it. Lucy looks perplexed.

‘I’m not the “previous tenant.” There was no previous tenant. I thought maybe you had the wrong place. But how did you know about the paw prints?’ Lucy is baffled. She thinks for a moment, then digs in her bag for a pen and paper.

Julian pulls up in his pickup, after work. The flag on the mailbox is up. He opens the box. Lucy’s new letter is inside. He looks at it as he walks along the jetty. It has a return address: 1620 RACINE.  20.
As Julian lets himself in, something leaps onto him.
Agh! What -- It’s the stray dog, which Julian has evidently kept. It licks Julian’s face. (We notice, if we haven’t before, that this dog looks a great deal like Lucy’s dog.)
Oh yeah. You. He puts the dog down. He opens Lucy’s letter and begins to read.

An architecture class. A half-dozen GRADUATE STUDENTS (black clothes, hipster/pretentious eyewear, etc.) sit around a seminar table. One student, HENRY FERRIS, 29, presents a project. A severe-looking professor, BURNHAM, 60, watches.

My project is informed and inspired by a metaphor of the loop, or fugue -- interlocking, repeating patterns in time and/or space that generate meaning and structural complexity via their contrapuntal interweaving and mutual interdependence, as much as by paradox and apparent contradiction. Around the table -- generally approving looks. Henry pulls out a rolled-up poster.

Specifically, as exemplified in the work of M.C. Escher, in his ‘Relativity.’ He shows the Escher engraving of a dizzying building, staircases and ramps leading around in endless, impossible loops. (CONTINUED)

..- which I have re-rendered and reconceived here as a real-world contemporary structure incorporating offices, public space, a food court, and a 12- screen multiplex. Beat. Burnham squints at Henry’s proposal.
So if I understand this correctly, you’re proposing to build this Escher engraving.
With some significant modifications, but essentially, yes. Everyone takes this in.
Interesting. I have only two comments, Mr. Ferris. Henry looks eager.

One, this makes no fucking sense at all. Two, the assignment was to design a single-family home. Don’t waste the class’s time, Henry. (turns to the class) All right, who’s got something we can build here on Earth?
Henry comes out of class, chagrined, walking with VANESSA (another student, mousy/arty look).
God, I mean what is the point of putting yourself out there in the visionary vanguard if you’re just going to get shot down?
I thought your concept was really bold.  22.
It’s like, if you don’t take risks as an architect, if you don’t at least try to push the envelope, you wind up, I don’t know, remodeling kitchens for yuppies...
Exactly. I --
(surprised) Hey! As he exits the building Henry sees JULIAN outside, waiting on the plaza in front of the school.
Julian grins as Henry comes over.
He’s back!
Believe it or not.
What are you doing here? You’re supposed to be this busy, important man.
Never too busy to look up an old friend and buy him a drink.
I am truly touched.
And I had to run an errand in town. Henry laughs. They hug.
It’s good to see you. JULIAN’S POV - OVER HENRY’S SHOULDER He sees Professor Burnham come out of the building. Their eyes meet. Burnham freezes. Then walks on, as if he hadn’t noticed him.  23.
Julian watches him go.
Let’s get out of here.
Crowded Chicago bar. Julian and Henry sit at a table with burgers and beers.
So. How’s life in condo world?
Well, it’s a challenge managing a project so big, sometimes it’s frustrating, but basically I --
Just tell me how much money you’re making.
Forget it.
Come on, a hint.
I bought a house.
That much?
On the Lake.
That much? Shit.
Don’t worry. I’m mortgaged up to my eyeballs.
Still. Lake House. God. I guess that makes selling out your dreams and betraying your talent totally worth it.
Yep.  24.
He clinks his glass against Henry’s and drinks. Beat.
You never think about coming back to school?
Never.
You sure? You’re content just to be this upwardly-mobile cliche.
Yeah. (he drinks) I even got a dog.
(rolls his eyes) Shit. INT. JULIAN’S TRUCK - NIGHT Julian drives around Chicago’s North Side.
Hank.
Yeah?
Burnham ever ask where I went?
No. Beat. Julian is silent for a moment.
You should have seen him rake me over the coals today. He hates me.
He doesn’t hate you. (beat) He hates your work... They laugh. Beat. Julian turns a corner.  25.
Julian walks down the street, looking for an address.
1620 Racine.
What is it?
I’m not sure.
Who lives there?
I don’t know.
So why are we going?
I don’t know.
Okay. Julian crosses the street, notes an address on a building.
Here’s sixteen hundred.
So sixteen hundred twenty should be... Henry walks to the next lot down. He is standing in front of a PIT. Just a recently-dug foundation, no building. They stare at it.
So should we buzz up, or what? Julian takes a piece of paper out of his pocket. Lucy’s last letter. The return address is correct: 1620 Racine.
Perhaps there has been some sort of mistake. Julian looks at the letter itself. It is dated MARCH 20, 2004.  26.

Lucy comes in, studying a new letter from Julian. We can read the words “Mistake... tried to deliver this in person... wrong address... also the date (?!)” She picks up the pad and begins to write, exasperated.
I got your last letter. I’m not quite sure I’m writing back but I guess I want to get to the bottom of this.
Julian in his kitchen, reading the letter.

By the way, for some reason the mail isn’t getting forwarded to me. I’ve had to drive up there to get it. Anyway, no, I did not get the address wrong. I know where I live. Okay, it’s ugly, but it’s not quite an open pit. Julian smiles.
And I know the date, too. It’s 2004. He laughs. This is some sort of insane joke.

Just curious: what year do you think it is? Behind Julian -- the calendar on his wall is open to the MARCH, 2002 page. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy studies a letter from Julian. CLOSE ON the date, underlined: “2002.” And the words -- AND STOP BULLSHITTING ME, PLEASE. She snorts, incredulous. The dog looks at her. She pets it, thinking. Then she gets up. (CONTINUED)

She goes to a closet and takes down a shoebox. It’s full of photographs. She dumps them out and begins sorting through them. She pauses to look at one. A younger Lucy with a BOYFRIEND -- MORGAN, 30, slightly bland good looks. They’re in each other’s arms, laughing, in love. She looks at it for a second, then puts it away and keeps searching. She finally finds the photo she’s looking for. It shows Lucy and some friends, outside at night, wearing T- shirts and jeans, with snow falling around them. She flips it over. On the back is an auto-printed date: APRIL 3, 2002.
WIND BLOWING fiercely as Julian arrives home to find the flag on the mailbox up. A new letter from Lucy inside. He retrieves it and walks across the jetty.
THROUGH the window we can see thick clouds collecting over the lake as Julian reads the letter.

Since you don’t believe me, a little warning. There was a bad flu going around in the Spring of 2002. I remember because there was a freak late snow, and after that everybody got sick. Julian rolls his eyes.
So, my mystery correspondent, if you really are where -- or when -- you say you are... I hope you’re getting plenty of rest and drinking lots of fluids. This is too much for Julian.
Snow, right.  28.

He crumples the letter and goes to throw it away. He’s about to drop it in the trash when he suddenly SNEEZES. It takes a second for this to register, and by the time it does, he sneezes again. He whirls around. OUTSIDE THE WINDOW -- beautiful SNOW is swirling into the Lake.

The mailbox is covered with a thick dusting of snow. Julian very tentatively opens it. He quickly slips ina letter and closes the box, almost as if he’s afraid it will bite him. He pulls the red flag up. EXT. MAILBOX - DAY (LUCY’S CONTINUITY) The mailbox is dry; it’s a warm day two years later. Lucy opens the box and takes out Julian’s letter. She puts the flag down. She opens the letter. It has a single line.

Lucy, hands shaking, takes out a pen. EXT. MAILBOX (JULIAN’S CONTINUITY) Julian stares at the snow-covered box. The flag is now down. He is starting to look a little freaked out. Also, he has the flu. He suddenly doubles over and sneezes violently. When he looks back at the mailbox, the flag is up. He nearly jumps back in alarm. He very hesitantly opens the mailbox and takes out... his note. The same one he just put in. He’s slightly disappointed, but also reassured. He relaxes a bit. He flips the note open and his jaw drops. Underneath his line “CAN THIS BE HAPPENING?” is Lucy’s handwriting, a single word: YES.  29. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy comes home, a little dazed. Her dog jumps up on her. She carries it into her bedroom and sits down on her bed.
Julian on his bed, nursing his flu, staring at the note, still struggling to believe this. His dog jumps up and settles into his lap. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy on her bed, writing.
(out loud) I don’t know where to start.
Julian reads Lucy’s letter.

I don’t even know the right questions to ask. Is there anything you can tell me that might shed some light on this? Julian thinks. He looks at the paw prints tracking into the house. INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy reads. CLOSE ON a line from Julian’s letter: I THINK WE HAVE THE SAME DOG.
Lucy at her desk. She writes back.
Does yours jump on you when you come home and scare the shit out of you?  30.
Julian reads this.
Yes. He turns the page.

(reads aloud) ‘And does he sleep like a person?’ He looks over at his bed. His dog lies asleep on his back, mouth open. He does look like a person. Julian starts to laugh. He looks back at the letter.
I call him Jack. He looks at the dog.
So you’re Jack. (correcting himself, in amazement) You... will be Jack.
Lucy exiting a train in the morning rush hour.
Maybe we should introduce ourselves properly.
Lucy arrives at the hospital, signs in, gets a stack of charts and files.
I’m a doctor -- a first year resident in internal medicine.
Julian directing activity and conferring with Mona and Mulhern at the worksite. (CONTINUED)
I build houses. I mean, I help run a company that builds houses.
Lucy reads.
Okay. I’m still trying to get this straight. If in two years you’ll be living in an apartment building at 1620 Racine... which doesn’t exist yet... where are you, uh, ‘now’? Lucy shakes her head.
I’m in medical school, Madison, Wisconsin. (she looks around, writes) I mean, in ‘my’ now I’m ina hospital cafeteria in Chicago, Illinois, but for you... Okay, this is weird. This is weird.
Julian, on a break, scribbles on a pad.
What’s it like in 2004?
Lucy rides him from work. Train packed with weary commuters.
It’s amazing. Everyone drives these flying cars. We all dress in shiny metal jumpsuits. Oh, and the Cubs won the series last year.
Julian reads, smiling.  32.
Actually, nothing’s changed much. No. Cell phones are a little smaller... INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy watching Back to the Future on TV. Doc Brown is yelling at Marty McFly.
(on TV) Great Scott, Marty, do you realize what you’ve done? You’ve upset the entire space-time continuum!
Lucy writes.
Okay. One thing worries me. What if, in sending these letters, in communicating like this, we accidentally tamper with the course of time itself, altering human history forever in the process?
Julian walks across the jetty.
Yeah, good point. lLet’s not do that.
He lets himself into the house. Jack jumps up onto him.
Aggh! (firm) No. He sets Jack back on the floor, immediately goes back outside and comes in again. Jack jumps up. Julian puts him on the floor firmly and holds him there.  33.
No. Julian repeats this several times. Finally he enters and Jack stays down. Julian gives him a treat.
Good boy! INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - CORRIDOR Lucy reads the latest letter as she gets out of her elevator.
Sorry. I did have to change one thing. Lucy opens the door. Jack is sitting placidly, looking up at her.
You’re welcome.
beginning to laugh -- the first time we’ve seen her enjoy any sort of release, and we --
It’s a bright, warm day. Lucy at the mailbox. She pulls the flag upright.
Thanks for the favor. Here’s one back at you.
Overcast, cold, wind. Julian opens the mailbox and pulls something out. He keeps pulling -- it’s a long, bright scarf. He tries it on, surprised.
Put this on and don’t take it off for the rest of the month. It’s onna stay cold till the middle of pril.  34.
Julian fills a cement mixer. He’s wearing jeans, work boots, work gloves -- and the scarf. Mulhern looks askance at him.

EXT. LUCY’S APARTMENT BUILDING/EXT. LAKE MICHIGAN SPLIT SCREEN. Julian and Lucy both writing. Lucy on the roof of her building, where she can see the Lake behind the city buildings; Julian on the shore with Jack in his pickup. It’s warmer in both continuities: Spring is here,
If we’re going to keep doing this, we’ve got to know more about each other. Send me lists.
Julian in the kitchen. He has a cocktail recipe book and has set out gin and lime juice and a cocktail shaker. He mixes a drink as Jack watches.

Okay. Let’s see. I like dogs, as you know. Gimlets -- that’s gin and lime juice, delicious on a warm night. I like the Stones’ Exile on Main Street. Jane Austen. I like... I love... my work. (joking) Turnoffs: cruelty, infectious diseases, and guys with mustaches. Julian tastes the gimlet and smiles.
Lucy, sipping a milkshake, goes up the steps of the museum.
For me: Milkshakes, black and white. Money Jungle by Duke Ellington. Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman in Notorious... The Art Institute of Chicago on a quiet afternoon.  35.
Lucy stands in front of a canvas of boats on the water.
I forgot one. I like the Lake House.
A MATCHING SHOT, of Julian looking at sailboats on the actual Lake.
How’d you wind up living here, anyway? INT. LUCY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lucy sprawls on her bed, writing.

I rented it after med school. It was the strangest place I’d ever seen. I couldn’t imagine anyone building it. Or... I couldn’t imagine building it and then not living here. I loved the way it sort of... hovered over the water. I loved that jetty. I don’t know why.
Sunset. Darkness falling over the water. Julian sits on the jetty, writing.
You have to leave land to get to the front door. It’s like getting on a ship. Every time you come home you’re embarking on a voyage. (he winces) Sorry. Pretentious.
Lucy writing.
Don’t apologize. You can be pretentious. You can be anything you like.  36.

A small party is in progress for Costello’s birthday. Cake and coffee, a dozen doctors talking, laughing. After the toast, FIND Anna Klyczynski looking around. She goes out into the corridor. She sees Lucy, sitting alone at the end of the hallway, deeply engrossed in her letter.
Julian writing intently at his desk. Mona is watching him from across the room.
A few weeks have passed. WIND blowing fiercely on a late spring Chicago day. Lucy waiting for the train on a crowded platform. Her CELL PHONE rings.
Hello? (her explanation changes) Oh. Hi.
Lucy still on the phone. She sounds upset.
(on phone) Look, it’s not easy for me, either. You know that... no, I’m not mad that you called. I just... I’m sorry, I’ve got to get to work and I -- A train is approaching the station.

I don’t think that’s a good idea. No. Morgan, I’m saying please don’t come down. Because we need more time... Especially if we’re going to stay friends. I just don’t think we should... The train is about to leave.  37.
(on phone) Look, I gotta go -- She runs for it but the doors close in her face and she groans in frustration.
Lucy near the end of her shift, about to check out. Madhvi Patel approaches her.
Lucy. I need a favor. I've got to have the night off. Take my shift?
Tonight?
(shyly) Please? I've got a date. He just asked me, and I really want to. I'll cover for you next time. Lucy's exhausted, but she nods. She watches as Madhvi dashes off excitedly.
Lucy after her double shift struggles down the street with armfuls of groceries, Jack tugging at a leash. Car HORNS BLARING. A BIKE MESSENGER nearly runs her down. She looks strung-out.
Julian opens the mailbox to find it empty. He's surprised at how disappointed he feels.
Hey, pen pal. You haven't written for awhile.
Lucy soaks in a tub, looking drained, reading this letter.  38.

It's been a... rough week. I worked 30 hours straight. I haven't been able to get away. I can't remember the last time I looked at the sky, or saw a damn tree. (beat) It's not so bad when I'm busy. It's when I have a minute to breathe, to look around, that it seems really hard. I wonder what the hell I'm doing here, alone, in this gray city. And I miss the way the world looked from the window of the Lake House.
Julian reads this letter. Beat. He looks out the window. OUTSIDE are dozens of INFANT TREES waiting to be planted on the construction site.
Lucy, coming home from work on the train. Out the window she can see it's beginning to rain. She sighs.
Julian drives toward Chicago on a cloudless evening. In the back of his pickup truck is one of the TREES.
Lucy trudges down the rainy street toward her building. A CLAP of THUNDER and the rain begins falling really hard, sheets. She yelps and starts running for her door.
Julian digs a HOLE outside the construction site that will become Lucy's apartment building. He finishes and starts to set the tiny, fragile tree in place.

Lucy is completely soaked as she runs the last few yards to her front door. She struggles for her keys, dropping them, growing more and more frustrated as the rain absolutely pounds down on her, when suddenly -- IT STOPS. She is baffled, as THUNDER and lightning continue to crack across the sky, and indeed the rain is still falling all around her, but not ON her. She looks up. Above her are the branches of a YOUNG TREE, leaves grown thick and high enough to form a canopy swaying in the rain just above Lucy. It wasn't there a second ago but now it's sheltering her, and she gapes at it.
Julian smiles as he tosses the shovel in the back of his truck.
ON Lucy, moved, her face breaking into a wide smile.
(quietly) Thank you. Drops of rain fall through the green branches as Lucy spins slowly beneath the tree.
Henry is standing on the jetty facing the Lake House. He has just arrived.
You... bastard... Julian gestures for Henry to follow him inside. Henry is too flabbergasted by the house.
This is where you’ve been hiding out? This is yours?
Yeah. Henry follows Julian inside, appraising the place.
When was it built?
Seventies. You want a beer?
Yeah. Henry looks around.
It’s like Le Corbusier meets Frank Lloyd Wright meets... me in five years. It’s perfect.
Actually, it’s not.
They stand on a narrow ledge that runs along the back of the house. There’s a fifteen-foot drop down to the water.
You can’t swim. There should be a stairway down to the water. Maybe a porch. Something.
(shakes his head) It would ruin the line. Total aesthetic catastrophe.  41.
They sit in the darkness, listening to the WATER LAPPING, drinking beer. ROLLING STONES ON the STEREO inside.
Exile. Cool.
Yeah. Beat.
Julian. I didn't just come up here to escape my pathetic existence in the city.
You didn't?
No. There's an agenda. (beat) If you dropped this bourgeois 'thing' and came back we could still graduate together in a year. Start the Firm.
"Visionary Vanguard Associates.’
Visionary Vanguard. I can't do it alone.
(shakes his head) Sorry, Hank. Beat. Henry treads carefully.
I'm sure if you talked to him...
Forget it.
Jules.
He doesn't want me back. I don't want to be back. Everybody's happier now.  42.
What about your work? Your work was great. Even he admitted that. Look, I know it's hard, but if you suck it up and put all the personal shit aside for a few months, you'll have your degree, and --
I said forget it. His tone is sharp. Henry is quiet.
Sorry. I just... like it up here.
Are you involved with somebody?
(beat)
Why did you hesitate?
I didn't.
Yes you did.
I -- I'm not involved with anybody, okay?
Okay. (beat) All I'm saying is, maybe you should think about the future. Julian starts to laugh. He can't stop. Henry looks at him.
What? (as Julian keeps laughing) What?
Lucy has an old 2002 filofax calendar open on her desk. She turns the pages until she sees an entry, circled: "5:46 TO MADISON." She picks up a pen, writes.
Let's try something.
Julian driving. He turns into the parking lot of a local train station, parks and gets out. Rain is falling. BEYOND, a train is just pulling into the station.

Around 'your' time two years ago I lost something. At a train station. I was on my way back to school and I left it on the platform. See if you can find it for me. I won't tell you what it is. Then put it in the mailbox. This is your mission if you choose to accept it.
Julian walks through the station. A few PEOPLE about. He looks for single women. He doesn't see any -- just a couple of FAMILIES, an ELDERLY COUPLE, some BUSINESSMEN.

Final call for the 5:46 to Madison, making the following stops... Julian keeps searching. No luck. Suddenly, THROUGH the window that looks out onto the train platform, he sees a YOUNG WOMAN stand up and prepare to board the train. It's Lucy -- here two years younger, a med student. Julian doesn't know for sure that it's her, but she could be the person he's looking for, and she's startlingly pretty besides. He hurries through the door out onto the train platform.

He is about to go over to her when he stops. She has her arms around a MAN whose BACK is TO us. They're embracing under an umbrella, saying goodbye. Neither has noticed that Lucy has left a book on the bench where they were sitting. Julian sees it, but it would be awkward to go over and interrupt the kiss. He hesitates. The TRAIN CONDUCTOR announces final boarding. Lucy reluctantly breaks off from the man and gets on the train. The man Lucy was kissing doesn't move. He stands under his umbrella, watching as the train pulls out, and doesn't leave until it is completely out of sight. He never notices the book. Julian watches him go. Once he's gone, Julian goes over to the bench. He looks at the book Lucy left. It is a well-worn copy of PERSUASION by Jane Austen.
Lucy driving along the lake, eager to get to the mailbox. She passes a LAKESIDE CONDO DEVELOPMENT. It's new, upscale, sprawling. Lucy mutters to herself.
Tacky. She drives on.
Lucy arrives at the Lake House and drives up to the mailbox, eager. She opens it. There's no book inside. Just a note. She opens it.
She's a little disappointed.  45.
Lucy changes clothes after work. In the b.g., Patel and Costello are also heading out.
Going to the fireworks, I guess. I go every year. Why?
Julian drives toward the Loop, buildings glimmering in the twilight.
What do you say we both go? EXT. HOSPITAL - NIGHT (LUCY’S CONTINUITY) Lucy walks out onto crowded downtown streets.
You're not asking me out, are you?
No, no. I just thought it might be good to do the same thing, that's all.
The same thing, two years apart.
Julian has parked his truck and joined the crowds moving down the streets.
Better than staying home. They arrive at the SAME CORNER from different directions.

Okay. Let's go to the fireworks. SPLIT SCREEN -- they both turn the corner, in both continuities -- and suddenly the RIVER is before them, thronged up and down with crowds of PEOPLE gathering in the warm summer night.  46.

Julian stops at an Italian sausage stand run by a VENDOR in his 50s and an OLD MAN, the Vendor's father, who must be at least 80. The Vendor is about to hand Julian a sausage but his father stops him, piles some more onions and peppers on it for Julian.
Give the man his money's worth. (to Julian) I'm still teaching him the business.
(laughing) All right, Pop. Julian continues down to the river.
Lucy stops at the sausage stand. The Vendor is two years older, a bit sadder-looking. He tends the stand alone.
One, please. He nods, piles it high with onions and peppers.
Did you go to the station? I never got my book.
Julian walks through the crowds. He watches a HAPPY COUPLE go by.
Let me keep it for a while. I want to read it. (beat) There's something I've been meaning to ask you. Who was the guy at the train station?
Lucy watches a DIFFERENT HAPPY COUPLE pass (and is surprised to see that it's Patel and Costello, holding hands away from the hospital, furtive lovers).  47.
Julian stares up at the sky, in the middle of an expectant crowd, waiting for the fireworks.
Your fiance? Why didn't you tell me?
You don't tell me about your love life.
Because I don't have one. Unfortunately. God, I can't believe you didn't say you're married.
Lucy in her crowd by the river.
(gentler) I'm not married. We broke up when I moved to Chicago. CHEERS as the show begins and the first FIREWORKS EXPLODE. She looks up at the sky.
I'm alone.
Julian alone in the crowd as his fireworks show begins.
Okay. Me too. FIREWORKS EXPLODE AND ECHO in both continuities. Julian and Lucy watch, the lights playing on their upturned faces.
Lucy comes home. It's a hot night and her apartment is stifling. She gets ready for bed, stripping down to panties and tank top, and stands in front of a fan.
So. How were your fireworks?  48.
Julian strips down to boxers. He opens a window, trying to catch a breeze on his equally hot night.
Not as good as yours, I'll bet. They get better every year.
SPLIT SCREEN -- the two of them, lying in different halves of their beds.
Yeah... They both lie there, hot and uncomfortable, tossing in frustration, separated by time.

Then Julian jumps up. He goes to his desk and pulls out a piece of paper. He writes: AT THE TRAIN STATION, I... He crosses this out and starts over. WHEN I SAW YOU... I WASN'T EXPECTING... He crosses this out too. Then takes a breath, and before he can stop himself, writes: YOU DIDN'T TELL ME YOU WERE SO BEAUTIFUL.
Lucy reads these words. She can’t suppress a startled little gasp. She looks around, embarrassed. No one has heard her. She writes:
No fair. You saw me but I still don’t know what you look like.
Julian looks in the mirror, examines his hairline. (CONTINUED)
You're right. I wouldn't mind knowing what I'm like in two years. Why don't you get together with 'me' in the future and let me know what you think?
Lucy considers this.
Yeah. She takes a breath, suddenly excited and nervous. Her life could be about to change. She writes:

head_text.subj: OKAY... WHY NOT GIVE ME A CALL ON JULY 10, 2004, AT ABOUT

text: She checks her watch. It's 9:04. She writes. 9:05.

as it finishes the last curve of the "5" -- The PHONE RINGS. She nearly falls out of her chair. Lucy steadies herself. She gets up and crosses to the phone. She hesitates, then snatches up the receiver, heart racing.
(whispers) Hello?
(on phone) Lucy?
Yes?
(on phone) It's Morgan.  50.
It takes a moment for this to sink in.
Morgan?
(on phone) Yeah. I’m in Chicago. I came down for a meeting but it was cancelled, so I thought I'd give you a call. What the hell. See if you were free.
Lucy walks with MORGAN -- the man from the train station, now two years older than when we last saw him, good- looking, nicely dressed. They walk in awkward silence.
Thanks for coming out.
Sure.
Been too long. She doesn't answer. Beat.
How's Jack?
He's good.
Adjusting to city life?
Yeah, he's doing great.
Good. I miss him. Beat.
Have you eaten, by any chance?  51.
No, but --
Neither have I. I just realized I'm starving. We could grab a quick dinner. Lucy nods, reluctantly. They are passing a small, elegant restaurant -- "IL MARE."
How about this? Looks all right.
Oh, no, Morgan, this place is much too... But Morgan is already heading inside.
The place is small and stylish and serene. Also absolutely packed. Morgan goes up to the HOSTESS.
Two for dinner.
(taken aback) Tonight?
Yes, please.
I'm sorry, sir. We're completely booked for tonight. She pages ahead through the reservation book.
But three... no, I'm sorry, four months from now we have a dinner opening if you'd like to reserve. Five-thirty or eleven-thirty? ON Morgan, disappointed.
Bright, garish pizza place. Morgan and Lucy eat.
She looks He shakes 52.
Don't feel bad. It's the best restaurant in the city. No one gets a table.
It's not that. (beat) I didn't do this right. at him.
You didn't have a meeting, did you? his head. She waits for him to continue.
I thought you'd see me if it seemed like no big deal, a surprise, a quick coffee... But coffee could turn into dinner. And dinner could turn into... She shakes her head.
What?
Anything.
So this was an ambush.
I guess so.
Another one.
What do you mean?
Morgan. You were always leaping ten steps ahead. A week after we met you had our whole lives mapped out. When I was still at school, you were picking out real estate. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
I'd come visit for the weekend and you'd have all your high school friends, the whole town at the house to meet me.
At least I didn't make out with somebody else.
What are you talking about?
At the party...
Oh my God. I didn't make out with him! I kissed him, once, and it was just some random guy and it was years ago... I can't believe you even remember that.
Okay. You’re right. I don’t want to fight. (beat) It’s just... part of me wonders... if I had moved to Chicago when you wanted to --
You didn't. (beat; gentler) Leaving was the toughest decision I've ever made. I hope you know that.
Yeah. (sighs) I'm sorry. I never should have called. I just... miss you. Lucy doesn't answer. He pokes at his food, miserable.
Julian is parked in his truck outside the ARCHITECTURE SCHOOL. After a moment he gets out.  54.
Burnham, the architecture professor, at work at his desk. A SOUND at the door. He looks up. Julian is standing in the doorway.
(quiet) This is a surprise.
I was in the neighborhood... He trails off, uncomfortable. Beat.
How've you been?
I'm well. Burnham doesn't say anything else. Julian steps into the room, tentative.
How's Margaret?
She's in London for the year, teaching. Otherwise the same.
You ever gonna marry her?
Did you come here to make small talk?
No. Julian puts an envelope on Burnham's desk. Burnham looks inside. A check.
What is this?
It's what I owe you.
I beg your pardon?
You paid my tuition for two years. (CONTINUED)
So?
So you wasted your money.
I really don't think we owe each other anything.
I'd feel better.
(shrugs) If it makes you feel better. Burnham looks at the check briefly, pockets it. Beat.
There's something else. I bought the house.
I heard a rumor. Word travels in this business.
Yeah?
Yes. They said some sleazy little developer building McMansions up and down the lake shore snapped it up. Julian stares at him for a moment. Then abruptly exits, slamming the door behind him.
Burnham takes out the check again. He looks at it, then slowly tears it in half and drops the two pieces into a wastepaper basket. Then he opens a desk drawer and pulls out a photograph.

It is a photo of the Lake House under construction. Burnham stands on the jetty with a lovely WOMAN and a small BOY, about seven. The boy points at the house, his arms around his father's neck. Burnham holds the little boy in his arms, smiling and happy and proud.  56.
Burnham looks at the photo a moment, starts to drop it in the wastebasket as well, then decides not to. He puts it back in the drawer.
It is now autumn on the North Shore. Trees fiery and gorgeous against the deep, vivid blue of the lake.
Julian steps out the front door of a COMPLETED CONDO -- the first one to be finished. He shakes hands with Mulhern, making a little ceremony of it. Applause from the crew gathered around.
Julian and Mona sit in Julian's truck looking at the site. Jack is in the backseat.
One down.
Forty-four to go.
We're not terrifyingly behind schedule. Just... alarmingly. She looks anxious.
It's gonna be okay. We'll catch up. We could use a couple more guys who know how to handle a backhoe. And the waterline to number fourteen needs to be resealed...
Shut up.
What? (CONTINUED)
I'm kind of pissed at you, you know.
You are?
I thought you were supposed to be on top of things around here.
I thought I was.
Well you never noticed these. She puts a foot up on the dashboard. She's wearing new, rather flashy red cowboy boots.
Don't you remember? You told me to get them.
Right. Right. (laughs) Wow. Not exactly what I had in mind, but...
You like them or not? He looks at them. He also can't help looking at her leg. She grins.
I like them.
Good. ‘Cause I was thinking... if you're not busy tonight, we should --
JACK suddenly GROWLS and LEAPS out of the window. Julian surprised.
Hey! (CONTINUED)
Julian scrambles out. Jack is dashing off over a hill. Julian shouts but the dog doesn't stop. Julian takes off running after him. Mona gets out.
Julian?
Julian chases Jack down a nearby residential street. The dog is speedy. Julian racing to keep up.

Jack darts across someone's yard. Julian still chasing. AHEAD, a MAN in his driveway is unloading boxes from his car trunk. He sees what's happening and, quick on his feet, manages to scoop Jack up in his arms as the dog dashes past. Julian runs up, winded.
Thanks.
No problem. The MAN is MORGAN -- here, two years younger than we saw him last. Julian has only seen him once before, under an umbrella in the train station, and doesn't recognize him.
He's never run off like that.
Gotta keep an eye on them. What's his name?
Jack.
(petting him) Hi, Jack. I should get one like you for my girlfriend. She loves dogs. Julian notes all of Morgan's boxes -- cases of beer and wine.
Let me give you a hand with that.  59.
Mona, far behind and hobbled by the boots (which are hard to run in), stumbles down the street looking for Julian.
Julian helps Morgan carry in the boxes. Morgan is a genial, chatty guy. Julian listening politely.
I do some real estate law, contracts, wills, whatever people need around here. Big stuff, small stuff.
Yeah?
(smiles) Okay, mostly small stuff. How about you? You lived here long?
Just a few months. I've got a place on the Lake.
Nice. They're done. Mona comes limping up, winded.
Oh, thank God. You found him.
Yeah. Morgan nods "hi" to Mona.
Hey, just so you don't think I'm planning to drink all this by myself -- I'm having a bunch of friends over tonight. Locals. You two are welcome to come. Julian and Mona exchange a glance.
Thanks. We've got plans. (CONTINUED)

No problem. Good to meet you anyway. See you later, Jack. Oh, hey, Julian -- (reaches into his pocket) Take my card? I might be looking to rent a place on the Lake myself. If you hear of anything, would you let me know?
Okay.
Thanks. I like this house, but my girlfriend doesn't. You know how it is.
Sure. Mona and Julian start off.
I promised her a Lake view if she moves here after med school. Julian stops.
She's in medical school?
Yeah. In Madison. She comes down on the weekends, though. Julian stares. He finally realizes that Morgan 1s the man who was on the train platform with Lucy.
She's coming in later tonight, actually. That's why I'm throwing the party. Beat.
What time does it start? Mona stares at Julian.

Lucy comes out after work, tired. Starts to head for the El. Then changes her mind and stops. She reverses direction and walks down the street until she comes to a bar -- the Cove, the place the other doctors told her about. She goes in.
The place is dead, mostly empty. She goes to the bar and sits down, glum.
Julian and Mona arrive at Morgan's house. Party in progress inside. Cars parked in the driveway, on the street. They start inside.
This better be good.
Morgan among his FRIENDS and NEIGHBORS, talking, laughing.
You wouldn’t catch me dead in Chicago. I grew up here. You'd have to be nuts to live anywhere else. I -- He stops Julian and Mona as they come in.

Hey! Glad you could make it. Bar's in the kitchen... They move through the rooms. A pretty dull crowd. Mona gives him a "why are we here?" look. No sign of Lucy anywhere. They eventually sit on the couch next to DOUG and MARJORIE, a couple in their 30s. Doug sticks out his hand.
Doug Ryan. (CONTINUED)
Julian.
Mona.

I teach Earth Sciences at the middle school. Marjorie coaches Speech and Debate. She's an expert in public speaking. Isn't that right, honey? 62. Marjorie nods but doesn't say anything. Uncomfortable beat.
You know anything about Earth Sciences? Julian shakes his head.
Anna Klyczynski appears and sits down at the bar next to Lucy. She orders a drink.
According to most accepted social norms a person should not drink alone after ten P.M., unless they have a good excuse. What's yours?
Don't have one.

I do. My youngest left for college this morning. Marie. (shakes her head ) There was this little girl splashing around in a wading pool in diapers in my back yard. And now she's packing her Volvo to drive to California. I have no goddamn idea where the time went. (smiles) She's going to be pre-med at Stanford. (CONTINUED)
That's great.
(proud) Yeah. (drinks) You want another one?
Yeah. Anna orders. The drinks come. Beat.
Okay. I do have an excuse.
Julian and Mona are still on the couch with Doug and Marjorie, looking restless. Doug is using two paper plates to illustrate what he's saying.
All of the Earth's continents rest on tectonic plates. Now these plates are continually moving and shifting...
(to Julian, out of the side of her mouth) Get the coats.
Excuse me for a sec, Doug. Julian gets up.
Morgan is looking out the window.
Okay, everybody! This is it! Morgan turns out all the lights in the room. Everyone quiets. (CONTINUED)
After a moment a figure carrying an overnight bag comes into the darkened room. Lucy.
Hello? Morgan flips on the lights. Everyone yells "Surprise,” "Happy Birthday," etc. Someone carries in a cake blazing with candles. Lucy looks stunned. Morgan kisses her. Julian watches.
Lucy and Anna at the bar.
Why didn't you mention it was your birthday? We would have had a cake for you or something.
It's just time passing. I hate making a big deal out of it. Anna looks at her.
You keep a lot to yourself. Lucy doesn't say anything.
Nothing wrong with it. But I've sometimes wondered what else you have in your life besides work. Family? Boyfriend?
I did...
Morgan enthusiastically introduces Lucy around, everyone toasting her, hugging her, etc. She's trying not to show that she's a little annoyed. (CONTINUED)
And this, this is Larry Wuchich. 'The Wooch' -- I've known this maniac since third grade...
Hello. They turn to the next guests. Julian and Mona. Mona eager to leave.
Oh hey. This is Julian. This guy's gonna help us find our Lake house.
Hello.
Hi. Morgan sees that they're holding their coats.
You're not leaving? Julian looks at them. Morgan's arm around Lucy.
No. We'll stay. Mona glares.
Julian is looking for a bathroom. He passes a bedroom door, ajar. INSIDE, Morgan is kissing Lucy. Julian steps back quickly. He overhears:
Were you surprised?
Yeah, I was. When are they going to leave?
What's the matter? (CONTINUED)
Nothing. Long train ride. I don't know. I guess I thought we were going to be alone tonight.
These are my friends, Lu. They’re going to be our friends. I want you to get to know them. We’re going to be making a life here.
I know. I know...
Lucy and Anna at the bar.
Beat.

We moved together after I finished med school. He rented this great house. Gorgeous place, up north, right on the Lake. His hometown. I did my internship. We were going to live there forever. That was the plan.
What happened?
It was his plan.
Ah.
No. That's not fair. I thought I wanted it too. I don’t know. Anyway, I ended it.
So who do you write to?  67.
Lucy says
I couldn’t help noticing. Every time you get a break at the hospital you're writing, or reading a letter. nothing.
Sorry. It's none of my business.
No. It's okay. There is somebody. (slowly) It's kind of a... long distance relationship.
How long?
Long.
How'd you meet?
We haven't.
What?
We just write letters.
You're kidding.
No.
You mean, like a pen pal?
You got it. Anna laughs, but Lucy looks morose. She drains her drink. (CONTINUED)

Story of my life. (beat) Keep everything at a nice, safe distance. Everyone... (sighs) The guy who was right in front of me, who wanted to marry me -- I push him away, I run. Meanwhile, the one man I can never even meet -- him, I want to give my whole heart to. Beat.
So you've really never spoken face-to-face?
Never. (stops, suddenly realizing) No. Wait. Once...

Lucy comes out of the party. The look of someone badly in need of a break. She sits. Beat. Then she realizes that she's not alone. Julian is out here too, alone. She nods to him. He nods back, not sure what to say, if he should say anything. Beat.
Happy birthday.
If one more person says that to me tonight I'll kill them.
(backing off) Right. Beat. (CONTINUED)
Sorry. I know it's no big deal. Just another year. I guess I'm not really in a party mood.
Me either.
So what are you doing here?
I was... hoping to meet somebody.
Who?
Someone Morgan told me about.
Ah. A fix up.
Kind of.
He's always thinking ahead, our Morgan. (beat) So what are you waiting for?
I'm trying to work up my nerve. She smiles, nods. Beat.
So. You're going to get us a place on the Lake, huh?
Yes. I am. She's a little taken aback by the confidence of his response.
Are you a real estate agent?
No. But I have a Lake House. (CONTINUED)
(puzzled) Oh.
And you're going to rent it after I move out. (beat) I mean, you could. If you want to.
When are you moving out?
I'm... not sure. I guess after you finish med school? She stares at him.
Morgan said you were in medical school... He trails off. Uncomfortable pause. Lucy is confused, and Julian feels he bas lost his grip on the conversation, if he ever had one.
What makes you think we'd like it?
You'll like it.
Can you swim?
Sure, I took lessons as a kid.
No, I mean, can you swim from the house?
Oh. He laughs. She laughs too.
Uh no. You can't. That's one drawback. There's no way down to the water. (CONTINUED)
That's too bad.
(nods) Yeah. As he talks, he moves over and sits down next to her.

(growing more animated) I've actually thought -- well, you'd have to see it, but I've always had this idea you could change it. Nothing major. But a few new elements would really transform it. A deck out back. And some stairs.
Stairs going down to the water?
Yeah. Just like a gentle slope, curving down... So you could step out the back door and slip into the Lake whenever you felt like it. Or if you just wanted to sit out there...
That sounds nice.
Lucy looks back at the house. Party still going strong. She sighs.
It's pretty late. Hadn't you better get back in there? If you're going to find your dream girl tonight?
Yeah... He hesitates, not sure what to do. He stares at her.
Lucy...  72.
Beat.
Yes?
(quickly) Have you read Persuasion by Jane Austen? Lucy looks startled.
It's my favorite book. (beat) Why?
I have a friend who likes it.
Your friend bas good taste.
Yes. She does. (beat) I've been meaning to read it.
You should.
I will. He sits down next to her.
What's it about?

It's about... waiting. (beat) These two people meet. They almost fall in love, but the timing isn't right, and they have to part. Then, years later, they meet again. They get another chance. But they don't know if too much time has passed, if they've waited too long, if it's too late for things to work out.
Sounds sad. (CONTINUED)
It's not. Not in the end. They're sitting quite close. She looks at him. She suddenly inclines her head toward his and their lips meet. A long, lingering kiss. After a moment she breaks off.
I don't know why I did that.

I'll try to explain... He is leaning into her again when... The door behind them OPENS and Morgan and Mona come out. Julian and Lucy quickly separate but Morgan and Mona can see they've interrupted something. Very uncomfortable moment.
Oh, Morgan, hey. Uh, Julian was just telling me about his house. It sounds really great.
(stony) Great.
(to Julian) We're, uh, definitely interested.
Good. I'll be in touch. (he stares at her. then, almost to himself) I promise.
Julian. It's late. Julian reluctantly gets to his feet.
Lucy rides home from the Cove in a cab.
My God. That was you. I remember you. Why didn't you tell me who you were?
Julian drives home through the darkness.
Come on. You would have thought I was insane.
As the scene continues, TIME PASSES for both of them (NOTE: we might see time lapse footage, etc.), although we experience this exchange as a single conversation.
(frustrated) But I liked you. That was our chance. You should have told me.
What about your boyfriend?
What about your girlfriend?
She's not my girlfriend!
Well, he's not my boyfriend!
He was then! I mean, he is now.
Your now, not mine! And maybe ‘now' would be different if you had said something then. Maybe now would have come sooner, or maybe now it would be our now, not just my now, you know?
No! I don’t! (CONTINUED)

IN HER APARTMENT, Lucy reads this, groans in frustration, and tosses the letter across the room. IN THE LAKE HOUSE, Julian, equally frustrated, tosses his pencil away. IN BOTH CONTINUITIES JACK dodges the objects, and we --
Henry is on a bench on the plaza, reading before class. Vanessa arrives, carrying a portfolio. She sits down on the other end of the bench. She looks at Henry.
Hi.
(barely noting her) Hey. He keeps reading. Beat. She jiggles the portfolio up and down on her lap nervously. Henry glances over and she stops.
Sorry. (clutching the portfolio) I'm presenting today,
You nervous?
A little, yeah.
There's no reason for you to be. She brightens.
Really?
Nah. Whatever you did, I'm sure he'll shoot it down. Her face falls. She gets up quickly and walks away. Henry is not aware that he's upset he (CONTINUED)
He reads a bit more, then checks his watch and gets up to go in. He sees something and stops.
Oh no. But he suddenly runs across the plaza. Vanessa is kneeling over a MAN who has collapse near the entrance to the school. It is their professor, Burnham.
Julian comes home. Jack waiting for him. He pours food for the dog, then notices his answering machine is blinking. He plays the message.
(on machine) Julian. Listen. It's your Dad.
Julian rushes into the hospital. He goes to the admissions desk.
I'm looking for my father, Julian Burnham. He was admitted today.
Mr. Burnham? Julian turns. A doctor is approaching him. Anna Klyczynski -- here, of course, two years younger than we've seen her before.
I'm Anna Klyczynski. I'm the attending for your father.
What happened? Is he okay?
He's okay. Walk with me. He's had a heart attack. Fortunately relatively minor, and his students got him here quickly. We're monitoring him. We'll probably want to keep him for a day or two.  77.
Henry is waiting outside Burnham's room as Julian walks up. He stands. Julian and Henry hug.
Hank. My God. Thank you.
Are you kidding? I'm just sorry I had to leave it on your machine. You all right?
Yeah. Julian breaks off, readies himself to go in. He indicates the closed door.
Is he sleeping?
No. Julian starts to go in.
Julian. I wouldn't.
Why not?
He's busy.
Busy? Doing what?
Evaluating a student project. Julian looks disbelieving. He starts to laugh.
Of course.

Can't let a little coronary throw off your whole class schedule. Julian shakes his head. The door opens. Vanessa comes out, carrying her portfolio. She walks up to Henry. She looks him in the eye. (CONTINUED)
He loved it. She turns on her heels and walks away. Henry watches her go, taken aback. Julian lets himself into the room.

Burnham is propped up in bed, hooked up to monitoring machines, reading. He has a lot of work with him -- professional journals and magazines, papers, etc. Julian walks into the room quietly, almost tentatively. Burnham doesn't hear him at first. When he does finally look over, he lowers his book but doesn't put it down.
Hi.
Julian sits at a table, writing.
I know I haven't written for a while. But I need to... I wanted to tell you about my father.
Lucy reads the letter.

He's famous. You know his work -- he built the Lake House. He sold it years ago, after my mother died. I guess he was trying to slam the door on that chapter of his life. Of course it was my life too. I got it back.
Julian stares at the page. Then writes another line.
That's just one of the reasons we don't get along.  79.
Julian brings Burnham a cup of coffee. Burnham is still up and working.
I m not supposed to do this. I had to sneak it past three nurses.
It's not decaf, is it?
No. Burnham takes it, sips, goes back to his reading. Awkward beat. Julian sits. Eventually Burnham glances over.
I don't need you.
I'm gonna stay until your test results come in.
That's not until morning.
There's no point driving all the way back up tonight. Burnham shrugs, goes back to his reading. The silence is deafening. Julian fidgets. After a moment he picks up one of the architecture magazines.
Do you mind if I...
Help yourself. Julian sits down, glum, and flips through it.
If that kind of thing still interests you.
Lucy continues reading. (CONTINUED)

I've made my share of small, stupid mistakes in my life. But I've made one huge, epic, massively stupid ultra-mistake. And that was going to architecture school to study under the great Louis Burnham.
Burnham is now asleep. Julian watches him breathing in the dimly-lit room, the monitoring machines blinking silently.

Everybody said I had his talent. zry te learn from the old man. Fo ow in his footsteps -- maybe all the anger and mistrust would just... melt away. Julian gently takes the empty coffee cup out of his father's hand. He picks up the papers strewn on the bed and stacks them neatly on the bedside table.

Right. Every class becomes a war zone. Every dispute inflamed by years of bitter feeling. Julian sits, trying to find a comfortable position to sleep in the hospital room chair. It's impossible. He stares at the figure sleeping in the bed.
Somebody had to surrender. So I did. I quit. (beat) And that is why, at the same age when my father was embarking upon a legendary career, I am throwing up condos and living in the old man's house.
Julian looks strung-out after his night in the chair. Burnham examines his breakfast tray, annoyed.
No coffee. (CONTINUED)
You just had a heart attack. Don't you think you can do without it?
Without it, I'll have a fucking stroke.
Julian brings the coffee to his father's room, annoyed. Before he can go in Klyczynski comes out, carrying a patient file. Julian is
There you are. Thought I'd missed you. We were just going over his results.
(disbelief) I was coming right back. He didn't ask you to wait?
No.
Jesus. really surprised and hurt by this. Klyczynski sits him down.
I'll tell you everything I told your Dad. He's going to be fine, as long as we do some intervention.
Intervention?
An angioplasty. It's quite routine, and it should prevent a repeat of the coronary episode. He's agreed to schedule for tomorrow, get it done quickly.
Whatever he wants. (CONTINUED)
Julian gets up and starts off.
You're welcome to go in if you'd like.
I've got to get back to work.
Don't you want to speak with him before the surgery? Julian hands her the cup of coffee.
Just give him this. It's all he wanted from me.
Julian drives back up North, grim. He arrives at the Lake House.

I don't know what I was expecting. I guess part of me thought, well, Dad's in a bed in Cook County Hospital, he's about to have serious surgery, it might go a little bit deeper than 'Is this decaf? (beat) But of course that's not how things work. When I quit school I rejected everything he stood for. That's how he saw it. So buying this house must have seemed like a sick joke. Maybe he was right. I don't know and it's too late to change things now. One thing's for sure: if I really was hoping for a tearful little bedside reunion. I'm as stupid as he thinks I am. (beat) Well. I seem to have poured my little heart out here. Sorry. Thanks for reading.  83.
Lucy reads.

I find myself wanting to tell you things I've never told anyone. Things I didn't know myself until I wrote them down to send to you. Maybe that's the strangest part of all of this. (beat) Love, Julian. Lucy lingers on this letter, on the last word, "LOVE." Jack trots up and jumps into her lap. She pets him, thinking.
Jack trots over to Julian's bed. He jumps up on it. Julian is lying awake, unable to sleep but it's too early to get up. He pets the dog. He has an impulse to pick up the telephone. He resists it.

Lucy comes into the hospital a bit early for her shift. She goes to an elevator and gets in. She punches the button for a sub-sub-basement. As she rides down she takes out Julian's letter and studies it.

head_text.subj: "DAD'S IN BED IN COOK COUNTY HOSPITAL."

text: Burnham is on a gurney being wheeled down the corridor toward surgery by an ORDERLY. He suddenly tries to sit up. (CONTINUED)
Stop.
What?
I've decided... Before I go in I want to make a call, please.
I'm sorry, sir, I got to get you straight into the O.R. You'll have to do it after. Burnham reluctantly nods.

Lucy searches through endless shelves of old patient records. She eventually locates a file labeled "LOUIS BURNHAM.” She spreads it open and begins paging through it. Past test results, etc. She turns a page and stops. A DEATH CERTIFICATE. She looks at it, disturbed. It is signed by Anna Klyczynski. The date given is two years earlier. Place of death: Cook County Hospital. Cause: coronary failure during surgery.
Lucy runs up to Madhvi Patel, urgent.
Madhvi. I've got an emergency. Take my shift.
Now?
I've covered for you. Please. Madhvi nods. Lucy runs out.  85.
Lucy drives toward the Lake House, very worried.
Julian gathers his things for work and walks across the jetty toward his truck.
Lucy stops in front of the mailbox and jumps out. She shoves a note in and yanks up the red flag. She stares at it, breathless.
Come on.
Julian driving away. He hasn't noticed that the mailbox flag is up. His truck recedes into the distance.
Lucy opens the box quickly. Her letter is stlll inside. She bangs on the mailbox, tears of frustration in her eyes.
Goddamn it. The flag stays up.
Julian working on a rooftop. His CELL PHONE RINGS.
(on phone) Mr. Burnham? this is Doctor Klyczynski at Cook County.  86.
Yes?
(beat) I'm afraid I have some difficult news.
Julian runs to his truck and takes off. Mona sees him dashing away. She calls after him. But he doesn't stop.

Julian arrives home. He is pale, stunned. He sees the flag on the mailbox. He retrieves Lucy's note, opens it and glances briefly at it before letting his arm drop to his side. The note drops, fluttering away, to land in the water beneath the Jetty.
The ink is smearing in the water but we can see the words
YOUR FATHER...”
Julian outside a chapel, in a dark suit, nodding at MOURNERS as they file in for his father's memorial service.

Julian. I am terribly sorry about your father. (beat) I knew I had to at least try to warn you. I thought I could get there in time. I hoped we could change what happened. (beat) I was wrong. I guess these things can't be changed. (MORE)

If they could, then the file wouldn't have said what it said, so I never would have tried to warn you... and then we'd be right back where we are anyway. It just goes in circles and I don't pretend to understand it. All I know is the shock feels fresh to me, even though it happened two years ago, so I can't imagine what it's like for you.
Julian listens, blank-faced, to the pastor. MOVING OVER the faces of the attendees, Henry and other students among them. FIND Anna Klyczynski sitting in the back. She looks like she hasn't slept.

These things just... happen sometimes. I know. Last February -- I remember it was Valentine's Day, but it was really warm -- I was at Buckingham Fountain. And something happened. I won't bore you with the details now, but it was rough. Not like what you're going through, but it bothered me a lot. And a friend gave me some good advice. She said to go somewhere that made me feel most like my true self.
The funeral reception is being held at the school. Examples of Burnham's work on display around the room. Julian shakes hands with other MOURNERS.
So I did. I drove to the Lake House. And that was the day I got your first letter.
After the reception, Henry and a few other STUDENTS help fold chairs, clean up.  88. CONTINUED ;
It's a place we both love, and it's a place your father built, so I hope you can find some solace there. FIND Julian sitting alone before a large photo of the Lake House, looking lost.
on the page of a book held by Lucy.

And I hope that whatever separated you will come to seem less important, and perhaps, in time, disappear. She is in the architecture section of the Art Institute bookshop. She takes the book to the front to pay for it.
Yours, Lucy. (beat) P.S. About the book.
Julian at the mailbox. He holds the book that Lucy has sent to him, along with the letter we've been hearing.

It won't be published for a year or two, so don't show it to anybody. But I thought you should see it. Julian opens to the first page. The title is LOIUS BURNHAM - LIFE WORKS. The publication date is 2004. Then he notices that Lucy has marked one page. Julian turns to it. It’s the photo of Julian at age 7 with his parents on the jetty of the Lake House. Julian stands on the jetty, staring at the photo.  89.
He sits, still looking at the same page. Then turns from the photo and flips through the rest of the book. Photos, blueprints, sketches -- a lifetime of complex, beautiful work.
admiration in his eyes.
Julian carefully selects a large sketch pad and some charcoal pencils from among the art supplies. He carries them to the front and gives them to the CLERK.
I'd like these, please.

Julian perches on the back ledge in the fading daylight, his feet dangling. The sketch pad is on his lap but be hasn't drawn anything. He looks down at the water, far below. He makes a decision and begins to write.
Lucy on her bed, holding the same piece of sketching paper. She stares at it.
Julian has written in charcoal "I WANT TO MEET YOU. FOR
Julian and Lucy write and pace, anxious and eager -- another exchange of letters that plays as a CONTINUOUS CONVERSATION.
How?
Pick a place. I'll be there. I promise. Tomorrow, what do you say?
Julian. It’s not tomorrow for you. You’ll have to wait two years.
I don't care. I'll wait. Go to the restaurant tomorrow and I'll be there. I'll be two years older but I'll be there.
What will you do all that time?
Think of you. (beat) And work out every day, get in shape, pray I don't lose my hair... Lucy smiles. Beat. She takes giddy.
Are you sure?
I've never been so sure of anything in my life. I've lost so much time already. I don't want to lose any more with you. a deep breath. She suddenly feels almost
See you 1n two years, then.
See you tomorrow night. (beat) Where would you like to go?
Julian in the restaurant talking to the Restaurant Hostess (here two years younger than we've seen her before). She leafs through the reservation book.
Well, I'm sorry, but we just received our fourth star and I'm afraid a reservation at this time will be extremely difficult. When were you hoping to dine with us?
Two years from tomorrow. September 15, 2004. The Hostess blinks. She closes the book.
We should be able to accommodate you, sir. DISSOLVE TO;
Lucy getting ready to leave for work. She checks an elegant, rather sexy new DRESS that she has hanging in the closet, ready for tonight.
Lucy finishing rounds. She returns a stack of files to the nurses' station and starts for the locker room, eager to leave. Klyczynski comes running up.
Lucy. We never got daily bloods from the floor.
What? The interns were supposed to...
The interns screwed up. Listen, if we each take half we can get it done pretty fast... Lucy nods, rushes off.  92.
Lucy waits on the platform for the train home, late, impatient.
Come on, shit...
She enters in a hurry, runs to the bedroom throwing off her clothes. Jack is watching her. She notices him. She takes a deep breath.
He's waited two years. What's another half-hour. Right? She continues her preparations, but at a calmer pace.
Lucy exits her building. She looks spectacularly elegant and beautiful.
Lucy approaches the restaurant. She stops before she goes in. She's ready: excited but calm, confident. She opens the door.
As she checks her coat she scans the room. There aren't many tables. Before she can locate Julian the Hostess comes up to her.
May I help you?
Yes. I have a reservation. Forster. Or Burnham, I'm not sure which name it's under. The Hostess examines her book.
Oh! Yes! You're the... (stopping herself) Follow me.  93.
Lucy is shown to a table for two. It's empty. She is a little surprised.
I hope you'll forgive me, but I can't help asking...
Yes?

(eager) This reservation is sort of... legendary. It's been here longer than-most of the staff. There’s always been intense speculation about who made it, and why, and if you'd actually show up. Some of the crew even have bets going... Lucy looks around. WAITERS all over the room are sneaking glances at her. CHEFS and BUSBOYS peering out from behind the kitchen door. Lucy suddenly feels very self-conscious.
(quickly) I'm sorry. I shouldn't have -- I'll send the waiter for your drink order right away.
A WAITER pours Lucy a glass of champagne.
Complimentary.
Thank you.
(can't help himself) Good luck. He darts away. She sips the champagne, nervous.
Her glass is empty. She is still waiting, alone at the table. The Waiter comes over to refill her glass, but Lucy stops him.
She is aware that the restaurant staff is watching her, whispering to one another. The Hostess shoos them away.

Hours have passed. OTHER DINERS are lingering over dessert, coffee, chatting intimately across the candlelit tables. Lucy still is alone. After a long moment she pushes her chair back and gets up. Everyone is watching her, grave. She makes her way to the front, expressionless. She collects her coat, not speaking to anyone. She exits. The Hostess watches her go.
Lucy walks home, alone. Her stoic facade begins to crumble. Tears in her eyes.
You weren't there.
A windy, grey day on the lake. Julian at the mailbox, reading the words "YOU WEREN'T THERE." He shakes his head.
(out loud) I'm so sorry.
Julian drives along the Lake.
I don't get it. Something must have happened. Look I've got two years. I'll try to fix it.
